Came during the celebration of Buddha's birthday, very beautiful temple! Beautiful gold Buddha's in the alter area. Free to walk in and participate in prayer, if you like, or just watch. Not too far from Gyeongbokgung or Insa-dong if I remember correctly. One of my favorite

We visited Jogyesa during Buddha's birthday celebration so the whole space had thousands of colorful lanterns hanging, creating this beautiful and peaceful canopy. I would really recommend stopping by. It's very close to Insadong
I only wanted to visit 1 temple and chose this one, it's very nice with 3 large buddhas inside and people actually use it. Outside is also very nice as is the area in general. Well worth a visit.
Big Buddhist temple in central area of Seoul. It is nesr Insa-dong street. It opens all peaple of any relition. Enjoy Koran temple.

The temple is centrally located in Seoul and easily accessible. It was decorated for the Lantern festival and was so beautiful. Such a beautiful place. Ended there after the Lantern parade and saw dancing and singing. So great!
We went there on may 7 th 2016. there are holding lotus lantern festival, the streets all full with beautiful lantern, very beautiful festival with many people and countries are participating.
Super accessible and always has community events happening. It is such a great place to experience practical Buddhism in Korea.

To be in Korea, this is in the middle of Seoul and close to other mayor attractions. For me it was very nice to be inside of a temple like this. Nice, nice.. We have the good timing because we went in the lotus lantern festival time, so everything was very well decorated. Nice

After seeing Buddhist temples in China and Tahiland I was not impressed with this one. It's nice if you have never seen any but nothing really amazing
I personally felt overwhelmed in this place, I did not go inside as there was a worship session taking place at the moment i arrived. Buda images are really impressive.

Nice and colorful temple, it is not so big but you can see enough what it has... I went with stroller with my baby and was perfect becuase they have all the facilities for handicap people
Buddhism seems to make people friendly, and lets them speak English better - may I add. We met super nice folks there and loved the layout and the nighlty illumination.

Absolutely beautiful temple. It's also up on a hill with lovely views. Remember to take your shoes off before entering the temple itself? A must see.
Located near the Palace, the temple is a great place to visit if you would like a break from the constant shopping and eating in Seoul.

The temple is located in one of the busiest streets in In-Sa-Dong. We stopped by as one of our group suggested who was a Buddhist. Once you walk in you'd feel calm and peaceful in no time. Couldn't stay long because of our rough schedule, but we truly enjoyed:)
I've only entered a buddhist temple once, it was not as big, but this one beats it. Probably the major difference was the presence of the sakura (cherry blossom) tree.

recommending, nice place to visit, save at least 2 hours, not so crowded as some others temples, lovely gardening as well
This is a Buddhist temple that's located right by one of the best shopping area called Insadong. Stop by after your shopping to rest and meditate as the temple is wonderful.
Very beautiful detailing around the temple, its small but if you look closely you will see how much time and effort was put into it! great site

Jogyesa is a temple in a Buddhist comlex (small museum, shops, ...) in a street where you can find buddhist souvenirs, callygraphy pens, etc. You are not allowed to take pictures in the Temple, of the three large presiding Buddhas. Many worshippers pray during the day and some

This is a beautiful temple in the midst of a bustling part of the city. Definitely worth taking the time to walk through it, especially if you are temple hopping!
Visited on our way back from the Changgyyeonggung palace. Don't waste your time and skip. Far from spectacular; Ladders and ciment bags all over. Need I say more ?

this is the first time I entered a temple. It is really beautiful. The decorations, especially the lanterns on the ceiling they are beautiful. it is clean and quiet. you will be seeing many donation of rice and waters in fronts.
Another one in a long mine. They all offer similar visuals, and this one does not disappoint. If in the area stop by...if not, well don't go out of your way.
Contrary to the reconstructed palaces that serve just a reminder of the old past, this temple is alive and thriving with spiritual life. Certainly worth visiting
Beautiful temple located in the middle of the busy city, very peaceful and it has a great old trees. Easy to cover this in 30 to 45 mins.
Not very big, but give a good insight to Korean Buddhism. The buildings are beautifully coloured. There is incense burning outside.

This gorgeous temple lies in the heart of Seoul tucked away from the busy streets. Although there is nothing particularly special about this temple, it is a lovely temple where you can escape the busy city and listen to monks in prayer.
Not far from Infamous Insadong, lays the quiet peaceful temple, Jogyesa. The buddha are huge. Its a real treat, Good for couples. I don't recommend little kids go, they would disrupt the prayer.
Visited early one morning amidst people worshipping on their way to work. This peaceful, earnest temple represents the impact of Confucious
At night the monks illuminate the temple with hundreds of bright colored lanterns. If you are lucky you will hear the monks chanting. A fairytale experience among the hustle and bustle of busy Seoul.

This was another nice stop on our free transit tour from the Incheon airport. Nice buildings - serene atmosphere. Active temple - "mass" in progress when we were visiting. Special to see the "old-world" temple in the middle of modern buildings.

Although the original temple was destroyed in a fire some centuries ago, and the current structure is a replacement, it is still impressive for its architecture, cultural significance and history, plus it was built without a single nail.
The temple is big and clean, very quiet although the room is fully filled up with prayers. Grad that we had managed to get there by walking from Hotel PJ

While ghetto emple was interesting we had more fun at the cafe within the complex having a traditional tea ceremony. There was also an art exhibition that was opening and the ladies were very pleased to tell us all about it and also wearing traditional costumes. Worth a visit.

We enjoyed our visit to this temple. We were welcomed at the door and even though people inside were worshipping we were permitted to take photographs. Well worth a visit.

Peaceful environment, Old trees, Golden color Buddha statues, situated at one of good locations in Seoul.... One can cover it in 30 mins..

Wonderful Buddhist temple set in a pretty garden with spectacular flower beds. There is an English speaking information booth if you want to find out more of the history. I was happy just wandering around and observing the peaceful and picturesque surroundings. Also the Shihan

We were at the Buddhist vegetarian restaurant across the street, and decided to visit this temple. It was so beautiful - the grounds had so many pretty flowers ... it was amazing. I have never seen any place quite like this.

They are having this beautiful chrysanthemum festival now with all kinds of sculptures covered in these flowers. Each pot of flowers was bought through a donation by individuals or families. In the temple area was a store selling some nice Buddhist paraphernalia.
The temple itself is also nice but I think the garden around is way more interesting. Worth to stop here for 10-15, not much more.
Well decorated with flowers. Beautiful even its a small area but well decorated. This is even suitable for elderly since the area is small and concentrated.

Autumn colors of Seoul include the colorful chrysanthemums that decorated Jogyesa Temple in Jongno, Seoul. It was a 10 minute walk from our Fraser Suites Hotel in Insadong. Get there via Jonggak Station, Subway line 1, exit 3. It would be easy to stop by after a tour of the
Beautiful small temple. Right next door to Insadong and Somerset Palace Hotel. There were lots of gorgeous flowers when I visited. My tour guide said they change them every season.

To study Buddhism, you can stay overnight here.some time it has special event like a lantern festival and flower festival. Please check the date with Korean tourism organization because the lantern festival like this review is up to lunar calendar.

There is a lot to see in this area but the temple itself is small. Definitely go if you are near by (Gyeongbokgung palace, Gwanghwamun square). Covered in flowers and very pretty but only took 10 minutes as we went past.

This temple is hard to miss as it is located between office buildings and the structure of it is too outstanding. A great place to visit as a buddhist or not. Learn about Korean Religion here.

Millions of flowers adorn the outside, the building itself is like a palace, just as beautiful. Very close to Insadong area to combine the 2. Make sure you take your shoes off if you go inside. Stunning.

The place is so full of spiritual aura and peaceful. Services were offered when we get there in celebration of Chuseok. You can see some distinctive features of the place like the pagoda, pond and old house.

An oasis of peace. The temple is used by many people and you can feel their spirituality. Besides the temple, there is a pagoda where you can honor people. By going to your left, you remember the dead. By going to the right, you are blessing those who are still alive.
We went on a half day tour and this temple was included the garden in front was just fabulous pretty and so peaceful

I found this almost by mistake and it was a very peaceful place despite being fairly central and next to the main castle grounds. There was a Buddhist service going on so I didn't want to disturb it and only have had a quiet stroll peeking politely inside. It is a living temple
Came here as part of a tour. This is a quiet reverent place. Mostly women and a few men here to practice their Faith.

After an exhilarating walk through Insadong or the palaces..stop by Jogyesa to reflect on all that you are. This beautiful structure with Bronze Buddhas is alive with worshipers and spiritual wa. Take care to respect the many engaged in prayer and take in the meaning.

Found this by accident and didn't realise I was so close to it. Very pretty and peaceful place. Especially nice when they ring the bell (end of the day in my case). Came back one night while prayers were going and quite serene.

Visited as a part of a City tour. Great location for Buddhists for praying and a beautiful Lily pond, and Lotus flowers. Great paper mache art and beaurtifully painted walls, ceilings in incredible detail. Stuff you just don't see now. It's a nice still feel and worth a visit.

another hidden gem right in the midst of downtown Seoul. Lively look at Buddhism. Inspiring and special place. The architecture, the deity figures, the lotus flowers blooming in the courtyard are all special

When in Seoul make sure you visit the Jogyesa Temple, the oldest one in town and worth a visit...note that not much English is spoken here, so you are on your own however you can hang around the Temple, visit all you like and most of all make sure you visit the 3 large Buddhas

Make sure one visits during the specified time as there are some activities for tourists especially with the lotus petals , nice harmonious place
A nice peaceful place, you can see the beautiful gold Buddha statues with in the temple. My highlight was seeing the vast amount of colourful prayer lanterns tha was hanging up outside.
I don't think you can travel to Seoul without seeing some local history. These temple are beautiful it is crowed but work going to any temple to view and see different cultures

One of the most beautiful places I've ever been. Really spectacular and breathtaking. You can also do a tea ceremony there (we decided not to) which would be a unique experience.

Stop by to offer some prayers there and feel so at home instantly! The temple is one of the oldest in Seoul and as Buddha devotee, we offer our prayers and even went inside for a peak of the temple prayers session. Remember to donate some to the temple!
Visited this temple in the morning and was blown away by the architecture and colors used. I even shot a little video as a commemorative piece to honor Asian diversity. Worth a visit.

My host took me here for a quick stop. She is Buddhist so she told me a little about it. We sat in for a little bit just so I can get a sense of their practice. It was very nice. It's a very beautiful temple as well.

A beautiful temple that we stopped by to visit on our Seoul City Tour. It was beautifully landscaped with many flowers! One of the most important Korean Temples with the largest Buddha shrine in Seoul. It was an easy stop.
I always like to go here each time I go to Korea. It gives me a sense of peace. I'm not Buddhist but I feel spiritual and my soul relaxes each time I go here.
The location of the temple is very nice with nice lanterns decoration. The temple is small with a lot of people. Nice to walk around and view the area

I really liked this temple because it had a nice central location in Seoul and was impressive with the Buddha statues. It's free to look around and you can spend 30 minutes to an hour taking pictures before moving on to the next site.

Such a piece full place. You can have a wish written for 30000won and hang up by the temple stuff. They will also pray for you.

I just came across this temple. It's located in the center of the seoul. When I visited on May 1st, there were many colorful lanterns up above. My friends told you'll see the view only on May.

This is a very charming temple with a lot of action. When we were there there was a prayer, many, many people and lots of colors. When you're walking through the city anyway this is a nice place to stop.

This temple is just to the North from Jongak station. It's well worth a visit if you're in the area.
Beautiful, special and old in the middle of the modern busy city. Very close to Insadong. Lovely iand impresive. Well worth the visit.

Ok after visiting so many temples I'm always interested in what is different. In late March or early April they have some kind of lantern festival. There's are super cool and colourful, defiantly worthwhile.

Even if you are not into Buddhism, this place still worth visiting when you are in the town. The huge buddha statute inside of the main building, people studying and praying in front of it, the pretty garden, and the architecture...i can't list all.
Very neat place. I loved the wood working and intricate details. But, we visited during a service so we were limited in what we could get close to and had to stay quiet. Overall, I recommend it.

As a non-Buddhist, I am curious and easily delighted by the Buddhist temples beauty. Again this was the case: this temple looks very harmonic with the trees and the square next to it. I just wished there were more information available in English about it and its history.

This temple is close by Gyeongbokgung Palace so is not bad to check this out , the real beauty of temple can be 3 Buddha inside the main house and flowers designed in the temple environment .
Entrancing chants. Beautiful flowers at the chrysanthemum festival! Loved seeing tranquil setting in such a busy city!
